standard_metadata.standard_description: Understand that a set of data collected to answer a statistical question has a distribution which can be described by its center, spread, and overall shape.

question.content: Here's a box plot that summarizes how many eggs Maya's chickens laid last week.    **Find the range of the data.**   eggs

images.alt: A horizontal boxplot is plotted along a horizontal axis marked from 0 to 12, in increments of 1, labeled Number of eggs laid. A left whisker extends from 2 to 3. The box extends from 3 to 8 and is divided into 2 parts by a vertical line segment at 6. The right whisker extends from 8 to 10. All values estimated.

hints.content: ###Strategy  The range is the distance between the smallest (minimum) and the largest (maximum) data points:  $\text{range} = \text{max} -\text{min}$  So if we can find the minimum and maximum from the box plot, then we can calculate the range.

###Minimum, maximum, and range  Here's how we can find the minimum and maximum in any box plot:  [[☃ image 1]]  In our box plot, the minimum is $2$ and the maximum is $10$:  [[☃ image 2]]  So the range is $10-2=8$ eggs.

images.alt: A generic unlabeled horizontal boxplot is plotted without a horizontal axis. The leftmost point of the left whisker is labeled min. The leftmost vertical line segment of the box is labeled Q1. The vertical line segment that separates the box into 2 parts is labeled median. The rightmost vertical line segment of the box is labeled Q3. The rightmost point of the right whisker is labeled max.

A horizontal boxplot is plotted along a horizontal axis marked from 0 to 12, in increments of 1. A left whisker extends from 2 to 3. The box extends from 3 to 8 and is divided into 2 parts by a vertical line segment at 6. The right whisker extends from 8 to 10. All values estimated. The ends of the left and right whiskers at 2 and 10, respectively, are marked with dashed lines. The distance between the dashed lines is marked with a brace labeled range = 10 minus 2.

question.content: Here's a box plot that summarizes the average monthly rainfall of several cities.    **Find the range of the data.**   $\text{ cm}$

images.alt: A horizontal boxplot is plotted along a horizontal axis marked from 0 to 8, in increments of 0.5, labeled Monthly rainfall (centimeters).  A left whisker extends from 3.5 to 5.5. The box extends from 5.5 to 7 and is divided into 2 parts by a vertical line segment at 6. The right whisker extends from 7 to 7.5. All values estimated.

hints.content: ###Strategy  The range is the distance between the smallest (minimum) and the largest (maximum) data points:  $\text{range} = \text{max} -\text{min}$  So if we can find the minimum and maximum from the box plot, then we can calculate the range.

###Minimum, maximum, and range  Here's how we can find the minimum and maximum in any box plot:  [[☃ image 1]]  In our box plot, the minimum is $3.5$ and the maximum is $7.5$:  [[☃ image 2]]  So the range is $7.5-3.5=4\,\text{cm}$.

images.alt: A generic unlabeled horizontal boxplot is plotted without a horizontal axis. The leftmost point of the left whisker is labeled min. The leftmost vertical line segment of the box is labeled Q1. The vertical line segment that separates the box into 2 parts is labeled median. The rightmost vertical line segment of the box is labeled Q3. The rightmost point of the right whisker is labeled max.

A horizontal boxplot is plotted along a horizontal axis marked from 0 to 8, in increments of 0.5.  A left whisker extends from 3.5 to 5.5. The box extends from 5.5 to 7 and is divided into 2 parts by a vertical line segment at 6. The right whisker extends from 7 to 7.5. All values estimated. The ends of the left and right whiskers at 3.5 and 7.5, respectively, are marked with dashed lines. The distance between the dashed lines is marked with a brace labeled range = 7.5 minus 3.5.

question.content: Here's a box plot that summarizes how many eggs Corey's chickens laid last week.    **Find the interquartile range (IQR) of the data.**   eggs

images.alt: A horizontal boxplot is plotted along a horizontal axis marked from 0 to 12, in increments of 1, labeled Number of eggs laid. A left whisker extends from 2 to 3. The box extends from 3 to 8 and is divided into 2 parts by a vertical line segment at 6. The right whisker extends from 8 to 10. All values estimated.

hints.content: ###Strategy  The interquartile range (IQR) is the distance between the first quartile ($\text{Q}_1$) and the third quartile ($\text{Q}_3$) in the data:  $\text{IQR} = \text{Q}_3 -\text{Q}_1$  So if we can find the quartiles from the box plot, then we can calculate the IQR.
###Quartiles and IQR  Here's how we can find the quartiles in any box plot:  [[☃ image 1]]  In our box plot, $\text{Q}_1$ is $3$ and $\text{Q}_3$ is $8$:  [[☃ image 2]]  So the IQR is $8-3=5$ eggs.

images.alt: A generic unlabeled horizontal boxplot is plotted without a horizontal axis. The leftmost point of the left whisker is labeled min. The leftmost vertical line segment of the box is labeled Q1. The vertical line segment that separates the box into 2 parts is labeled median. The rightmost vertical line segment of the box is labeled Q3. The rightmost point of the right whisker is labeled max.

A horizontal boxplot is plotted along a horizontal axis marked from 0 to 12, in increments of 1. A left whisker extends from 2 to 3. The box extends from 3 to 8 and is divided into 2 parts by a vertical line segment at 6. The right whisker extends from 8 to 10. All values estimated. The left and right ends of the box at 3 and 8, respectively, are marked with dashed lines. The distance between the dashed lines is marked with a brace labeled IQR = 8 minus 3.

hints.content: ###Strategy  The interquartile range (IQR) is the distance between the first quartile ($\text{Q}_1$) and the third quartile ($\text{Q}_3$) in the data:  $\text{IQR} = \text{Q}_3 -\text{Q}_1$  So if we can find the quartiles from the box plot, then we can calculate the IQR.

###Quartiles and IQR  Here's how we can find the quartiles in any box plot:  [[☃ image 1]]  In our box plot, $\text{Q}_1$ is $5.5$ and $\text{Q}_3$ is $7.5$:  [[☃ image 2]]  So the IQR is $7.5-5.5=2$ dollars.
